Technical issues: Technical problems such as connectivity issues, platform compatibility, and server crashes can hinder the smooth delivery of the course, causing frustration among students and instructors.
Lack of engagement: Without adequate interactive elements, students may become disengaged and disconnected from the course material, leading to lower completion rates.
Difficulty in assessing student progress: Online courses often lack face-to-face interactions, making it challenging to assess student progress and provide timely feedback.

Limited feedback from students: Without regular in-person interactions, instructors may struggle to gather feedback from students, leading to a lack of understanding of how well the course is meeting their needs.

Balancing flexibility and structure: While online courses offer flexibility in terms of scheduling, it can be challenging to strike a balance between providing enough structure to keep students on track while also allowing for flexibility in their learning experience.
